from its quadratic dependence and passes through a maximum at
), indicating the emergence of a negative MR
As the field is tilted away from the
creases in magnitude. Despite this decrease however, the peak in the
MR actually shifts to a higher field, leading to a cascade of crossing
points as displayed in Fig. 3A. As a consequence, the angle at which
peaks (at constant field strength) shifts progressively away from
axis with increasing field (Fig. 3B). Comparison of Fig. 3B with
the ADMR data plotted in Fig. 2F confirms that the asymmetric MR
in LMO arises because of the emergence of a negative component
whose magnitude increases as the field is tilted away from a specific
plane. One might argue that a posi-
can also lead to the observed
asymmetry. As discussed in our previous work (
tropic positive MR must arise because of the field-induced one-
dimensionalization (i.e., decreased Fermi velocity along the
and, hence, enhanced scattering rate). Nevertheless, it is expected to
preserve the mirror symmetry with respect to crystallographic axes
rather than at an intermediate angle like
tropic positive MR, although being important to shape MR curves,
cannot account for the observed asymmetry (see section S5 for further
discussion of the anisotropic positive MR).
In Fig. 3C, the MR data are rescaled to remove the |cos
dence (as explained in section S2 and fig. S7). In this way, all the
initial slopes collapse onto a single curve, as shown in the inset.
Although the field scale has been substantially renormalized, the peak
plotted in Fig. 3D still exhibits its own maximum at a
angle, the influence of the negative MR is, thus, at its weakest.

corresponds very closely (in one of its two
possible orientations) to an axis that passes directly through the poles
denoted by [−2 0 1] as acknowledged previously in (
